Bob Shennan, the new controller of Radio 5 Live, is making it very clear, in his quiet but insistent manner, that he has indeed landed his dream job. "I feel I've been in training for it since I joined the BBC. I wanted it. It doesn't come up very often."

Radio 5 Live has never looked back since the high-profile relaunch by Jenny Abramsky six years ago, and Shennan is only the third controller of the highly rated sports and news network, which now attracts more than 6m listeners a week.

Abramsky, now reaping the rewards of her endeavours as director of BBC Radio (the most senior manager), first handed the baton over to the canny Roger Mosey - like her, a former editor of Radio 4's Today programme.

Mosey, backed up by executives such as Steve Kyte, has introduced a range of changes, including the versatile Nicky Campbell in the mornings. But then the competition suddenly became more fierce, and more vociferous, as Kelvin MacKenzie's Talksport switched its priorities from chat to sport, in an attempt to woo advertiser-friendly, cash-rich young males.

The thing that distinguishes Shennan from his two predecessors is that instead of coming from a news background he is a sports expert through and through - well versed in the tricky radio sports-rights market and in handling sporting stars.

"Just as Roger Mosey was absolutely the right person after Jenny - even though it was predominantly driven in audience terms by sport - I think I'm the right person now. I don't think it really matters what people's backgrounds are. It's how they want to move the radio station forward."

At 38, he is swapping that unhappy billet, head of BBC sport production for television and radio, for the pleasure of running a service still in possession of the crown jewels of sport. And he is doing so as the BBC news empire loses control of 5 Live, allowing it to slot in alongside the other four national radio channels under Abramsky. This, says Shennan, represents a perfect opportunity for the station to redefine itself. "I want Radio 5 Live to feel like a real radio station, not a BBC network made up of two strands, news and sport.

"When people come in to work here, I want them to feel they are working for 5 Live, as they do in Radio 1 and Radio 2. I want to blur the edges, smooth out the gear changes for listeners," he adds, referring to the abrupt shifts between hot news inputs and live sport. "There is a bumpy sound to some parts of the schedule."

The tension of being a hybrid and having to play two roles can't entirely be wished away with snazzier jingles or more sports news programmes. But Shennan sees strength coming from melding the two elements more carefully. For example, drive-time's Peter Allen co-presented the Open from St Andrews last month, and the breakfast show was broadcast from there in much the same way that the Today programme moves to Brussels or Washington for key political events.

Over the past 18 months or so, Shennan notes approvingly that there's been a push to beef up the role of sports news. "It's about making sure the whole of the radio station recognises the value of sport. I don't want there to be a sense that there are times when sport switches on and everyone in news goes home, or vice versa. It does happen. It's a very, very ambitious network with diverse tones of voice," he says.

Shennan, educated at Lancaster grammar school, joined the BBC from Cambridge University armed with an English degree and a stint at Radio Hereward. A radio sports trainee, he rose to become head of radio sport as the first, unsuccessful version of Radio 5 Live stumbled onto the air. He is surprised at how slow the commercial operators were in the early days to spot the potential of radio sport.

Given this pedigree, it is hardly surprising that Shennan is less keen on by-elections, prime minister's questions and rolling news. The news wing of Radio 5 is making fearful noises in private. Shennan, however, claims they have nothing to worry about. "There is not going to be a huge shift or a dramatic move away from news. I want to evolve the station, not revolutionise it."

Indeed, with digital radio expansion still some years away, 5 Live is unlikely to eliminate news or a commitment to breaking stories, such as the Paddington rail crash or by-election declarations. "My role is to build a sense of one radio station. I want to make a strength of the fact that we have these two distinctive strands."

The question of competition, specifically in the form of MacKenzie's Talksport, is one that he is keen to bring up: "I am very alive to the challenges we face."

Radio 5 Live gave an early demonstration of this new awareness when it finally took action this summer against Talksport's practice of covering events to which the BBC owned exclusive rights. After a year of hand-wringing, lawyers were employed when Talksport commentated on televised Euro 2000 matches.

"It's very sensible for the BBC to protect its investment, and increasingly, rights-holders will be pleased, rather than having to take action themselves. I see Euro 2000 as quite straightforward. We bought the rights to broadcast live and exclusive, and Talksport was not around when the whole process was negotiated.

"There were no national sports broadcasters when we launched. There certainly are now. Inevitably, we are challenged. The key part of our strategy is going to be maintaining that portfolio [of sports rights] in every way we can."

Radio 5 Live, he agrees, already has a healthy budget of £65m. Will it get more? It sounds possible. Negotiations are just opening for radio rights to the Premiership - 5 Live has them for one more year.

"We have to make sure we maintain the integrity of the output. We will bid competitively for Premier League rights. Holding on is very important for us," promises Shennan.

But, as he points out, 5 Live has done well (certainly far better than television) in holding on to the crown jewels - cricket, the Open, Six Nations rugby, formula one and the FA Cup.

But he could be inheriting the station as it peaks: "There is still potential; it could go further. It will depend on a number of things working in our favour. Maybe sports audiences are quite close to their maximum."

The key, therefore, is probably more attractive news programming and fresh thinking. Nurturing articulate sports stars with a background in professional sport is one of Shennan's pet projects. "I want to develop new, key talent," he says. He points to the way Gary Lineker, Steve Cram and Clare Balding have been brought on.

"I want to introduce new voices. Ian Wright and Mark Bright - now that could be a strong team." He goes on to praise John Inverdale, one of Radio 5 Live's stars, who has been tempted across to television. "He's not going to disappear - he's very symbolic of what 5 Live is about. He's a terrific journalist, with all-round knowledge, and a wonderful tone of voice."

What Shennan's appointment means for David Mellor's Football 606 - already moved from its Saturday slot - is less clear. "He's been a tremendous success at 5 Live. He's been here a long time, and he'll do it for the next season. But it's always my job to think about the future and refresh things."

'No-one else does it'

March 1994
Five months after being given the go-ahead, Radio 5 Live is launched with a new 24-hour news and sports format, replacing BBC Radio 5. "Nobody else does it," says its controller, Jenny Abramsky. Its £30.2m budget includes an unprecedented £1m advertising allowance. Personality presenters such as Ian Botham and David Mellor are among extra staff recruited.

August 1994
First detailed listening figures show a gain of 500,000 listeners over 5 Live's predecessor, with 4.7m tuning in each week.

February 1995
Talk Radio UK is launched, competing for the same listeners.

April 1996
Radio 5 Live is named UK station of the year at the Sony Radio awards for its sports broadcasting in particular - "so engaging that it makes listeners feel they are actually there at the event itself". Sport provides the largest audience, with up to 800,000 listeners.

October 1996
The editor of the Today programme, Roger Mosey, is appointed new controller of 5 Live.

March 1997
Football presenter Danny Baker is fired for urging listeners to doorstep a referee and make his life hell. Talk Radio signs him up.

March 1997
The audience for 5 Live's breakfast programme has risen to one-third of Today's 5m. Its listeners are younger, more regional and less upmarket.

December 1997
"There's enough sport around not only for 5 Live, but for us too," says the boss of Talk Radio, Peter Robinson.

April 1999
Radio 5 Live loses winter Test cricket rights to Talk Radio. However, it has 5.2m listeners a week, up from 4.7m in April 1994.

August 2000
Figures show a fall from 5 Live's record reach of 6.2m in the previous quarter to 5.8m. Slight share fall from 4.4% to 4.1%. Moves under Jenny Abramsky's control.

US vice president and Democratic party candidate Al Gore has selected Connecticut Senator Joseph Lieberman to be his running mate - the first Jewish vice presidential candidate in American history

Gore planned to offer Lieberman the job in a telephone call later today, according to several Democratic party sources. Lieberman has indicated he will accept.

The sources said Gore made his decision after discussions late Sunday night and early this morning with top advisers, including former Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who headed up his search process, his brother-in-law Frank Hunger, his wife Tipper and campaign chairman Bill Daley.

The vice president and his running mate are expected to appear together at a noon rally tomorrow in Nashville. Lieberman, 58, beat five other finalists: Senators Evan Bayh of Indiana, John Edwards of North Carolina, John Kerry of Massachusetts; House of representatives minority leader Dick Gephardt of Missouri and New Hampshire governor Jeanne Shaheen.

The Gore campaign hoped Lieberman's selection would be a bold stroke heading into next week's Democratic national convention in Los Angeles. He trails rival George W Bush in polls after last week's Republican convention.

A Democratic centrist, Lieberman would amplify Gore support of fiscal discipline and middle class tax cuts, the sources said.

Gore considers his pick a respected voice of independence and integrity, and the sources drew a contrast to the Republican ticket's ties to special interests. Lieberman was an outspoken critic of President Bill Clinton's conduct during the impeachment controversy.

Polls show Bush benefiting from the so-called "Clinton fatigue." Gore's selection of an Orthodox Jew is a first.

Because he and his wife Hadassah observe the Jewish Sabbath from dusk Friday to dusk Saturday, Lieberman is ostensibly prohibited from working then. The senator has interpreted this to mean he may still work during that time, but only to promote "the respect and protection of human life and well-being."

Thousands of troops have been deployed across the western United States as hundreds of wildfires yesterday burned out of control, apparently impervious to bombardments by flying water tankers attempting to halt the blaze.

President Bill Clinton is due to visit areas stricken by what has been described as the worst outbreak of forest fires in half a century. The government is spending $15m a day (about £10m) to support 20,000 civilian and military firefighters from 46 states and Canada.

The national interagency fire centre (NIFC) in Boise, Idaho, reported yesterday that there were now more than 70 large fires engulfing more than 750,000 acres in 11 states, notably Montana, California, Colorado, Nevada, Idaho and Wyoming.

Officials are alarmed that the blazes have come earlier than the usual fire season and that they are proving more difficult to contain. Some of the fires are thought to be so well established that they will only be extinguished by the arrival of snow in October or November.

"The northern Rockies is the hottest place in the country at the moment," said Lynn Pisano-Pedigo of the NIFC yesterday. She cited "dry lightning" as one of the main causes of the latest outbreak.

The weather conditions that produce dry lightning are expected to continue for several weeks - a combination of high temperatures, low humidity and rainless thunderstorms.

Temperatures have also been at record highs in many areas. Weather officials report "triple digit" temperatures in central California, making the land even more susceptible to the blazes.

Hamilton in Montana is at the centre of the main blazes and yesterday residents were warned to remain indoors because of the thick smoke engulfing the area.

More than 300 homes have been evacuated so far, and a further 300 were expected to be evacuated by late last night.

A total of 16 large fires were raging in the state, covering 135,000 acres. In Nevada, a helicopter carrying a firefighting crew crashed near Elko, killing one member and injuring three others.

In Colorado, the Mesa Verde national park was having to deal with a blaze that threatened the park's research centre and museum. More than 400 firefighters were trying to save the threatened parts of the forest, which is a popular holiday place, aided by helicopters and seven air tankers flying in to drop water on the blaze.

In California, the US forest service reported that there were more than 100 wildfires blazing and that some were in areas of brush that have not burned in more than 100 years. Two hundred people were evacuated from Jackson, Wyoming, three days ago and have still not been able to return to their homes.

Troops are being trained as temporary firefighters. More than 500 soldiers were dispatched from Fort Hood in Texas yesterday after training, to join 500 other soldiers and 500 marines fighting the fires in Idaho. A further 500 were sent to Montana to back up a beleaguered and exhausted fire crew.

The head of the US forest service, Mike Dombeck, said yesterday that the situation was now so serious that Canadian firefighting crews were having to be brought in to help.

Since the start of this year, there have been about 62,000 wildfires across the US. They have engulfed 3.76m acres of forest, almost double the 10-year average.

One of the reasons for this dramatic increase has been that people are going deeper and deeper into forested areas in the search for seclusion. Wherever there are humans, there is the risk of fires - usually started accidentally, from cigarette ends and barbecues, but sometimes lit deliberately.

It is now relatively common for people to start fires and then call the fire service and give themselves a heroic role in fighting the blazes.

However, while it would make ecological sense to stop people living in such areas, there would be a political price to pay in restricting residential areas.

Marines have been using various techniques to try to contain the blazes, ranging from bombing the fires from above with a mixture of slurry and water, to fighting fire with fire - burning swaths of undergrowth themselves to create firebreaks.

But unless weather patterns change, they appear to be fighting a losing battle.

The best-known and loved English actor of the 20th century, Sir Alec Guinness who has died aged 86, was by nature an unostentatious and reserved man. Though he undertook a great variety of roles, all were informed, at heart, with the wisdom of the sad clown.

It was that spiritual severity, together with those clear, wide-open eyes - capable of melting in close-up on screen into the most reassuringly serene of smiles - which lent his performances force and authenticity. In his later career, he became something of an icon of spirituality and enlightened human understanding - especially after his 1977 performance as Obi-Wan Kenobi in Star Wars.

His contract with George Lucas, guaranteed him two per cent of the profit: though the role had been much reduced, and he had almost left the production. The resulting financial security made this already fastidious actor even choosier about live stage roles. After Star Wars he appeared in only two West End plays, and was an unusual and sensitive Shylock at Chichester (1984).

But Guinness was not the first great actor to find the ability and the inclination to learn parts after 70 much reduced. He had avoided the theatre for six years before starring as TE Lawrence in Rattigan's Ross in 1960. More than any other English star of his generation, he was equally at home on stage, in film and on the television screen - where he had an Indian summer as John Le Carré's spymaster George Smiley.

Guinness had an impecunious childhood, and a modest south-coast boarding school education. At 18 he found employment as a junior copywriter in an advertising agency.

He describes in his discreet autobiography Blessings In Disguise (1985) how the acting bug had bitten him. On the recommendation of John Gielgud he contacted the formidable and eccentric Martita Hunt - the first woman he had ever met with silk trousers and painted toenails, he later wrote. She coached him for a RADA Leverhulme scholarship audition. But RADA was not giving the award that year, so he enrolled instead at the Fay Compton studio for as long as his money lasted (John Le Mesurier was a fellow student) and then went to work in the London theatre, debuting aged 20 in Libel! at the Playhouse.

In his unpretentious and beautifully written book, he exorcised a long-suppressed anxiety about his origins. He was, he made clear, illegitimate - his name a mystery, his father probably called Geddes, the circumstances of his conception, vague. For the rest, Guinness told the tale of his life obliquely, its focus firmly on loved ones and friends rather than on himself. He was there, as it were, in reflection.

Finally the question of his birth didn't matter to him, but in the beginning it must have. A reluctance to put himself in the spotlight - an almost neurotic discretion - was the mark of both his professional and personal style. In a 1953 monograph about him published by Rockliff, Kenneth Tynan wrote: "Were he to commit a murder, I have no doubt the number of false arrests following the circulation of his description would break all records."

While still only 20 he was a flowery Osric in Gielgud's Hamlet at the New theatre. Thereafter until the war, his career was spent at Old Vic, where he impressed with a modern-dress Hamlet in autumn 1938.

He always denied having any technique as an actor - or knowing what technique might be. Yet he was proud of his gift.

For Guinness the purpose of acting was to make-believe. The theatre was an act of faith, whose object was to tell the inner truth about situations and feelings, not to embroider falsehood with trickery and display. He was a master of disguise as he demonstrated in the Ealing comedy Kind Hearts and Coronets (1949), with an emotionally thankless multiplicity of roles. Denis Price, the villain at the centre, was the sort of charming role that Guinness later made his own, through a series of famous Ealing Studio hits.

But the Kind Hearts gallery of family victims was consciously broad brush. Guinness was an actor, not an entertainer or vaudevillian. The spiritual core of Guinness's inner conviction remained the same - whatever game of disguise he might play.

His conversion to Roman Catholicism followed an episode during the 1954 shooting of Father Brown (called The Detective in the US), in which he played GK Chesterton's cheery cleric. Walking back in the dark, still in a cassock, to the station hotel of a village near Macon after a drink in the local bar with Peter Finch, his hand was seized by a small boy, a complete stranger, who called him "Mon père" and trotted along beside him chatting in French.

Despite his phony credentials as a cleric, Guinness felt strongly that the reality of this trust was important. When his 11-year-old son Matthew was temporarily crippled from the waist down with polio, Guinness had taken to dropping in on church and praying. Shortly after Father Brown, he joined the church of Rome.

As an actor, he had acute and particular tastes, an infallible instinct for the apt moment, the ideal tone, the canny strategy. When he was Fool to Laurence Olivier's unsuccessful King Lear (1947), Guinness said that Olivier had been irritated that he had received the lion's share of the reviewers' favour. This was, said Guinness, a direct consequence of Larry's actor-managerish vanity. "Every time Larry came on stage, the lights went up in his vicinity. All I had to do was just stay very close to him." Guinness, of course, couldn't fail to be noticed if only because he was doing so little so well.

He knew his own vulnerabilities and exploited them with courage, to give some of his best performances. He had resented, for instance, Olivier's assumption in the mid-thirties that he was John Gielgud's boyfriend. Not because he could not have been, or was ashamed or offended to be cast in that role, but because he was not and they had no reason to assume it. In 1938 Guinness became a scrupulous husband and father - though his sexuality was complex.

Typically he did not balk at playing the transvestite professional criminal Mrs Artminster in Wise Child (1967) with the then glamorous-looking Simon Ward. His Lawrence in Ross rang dangerously true to self. Being mixed-up, discreet, acutely intelligent and voraciously well-read fuelled the neurotic-but-muffled engine that drove him as an artist.

Being so private a personality let him bring out the normally hidden interior aspects of Harcourt Reilly in TS Eliot's Cocktail Party. He played this role, the Unidentified Guest, at Chichester, the Wyndham's and the Haymarket in 1968 and 1969, as well as in Edinburgh and New York in 1950. His reading of Eliot's Four Quartets on radio was spell-binding. He was perfect material for Alan Bennett's Old Country (1977) and Habeas Corpus (1973). In the latter he devised and performed alone a typically self-revealing dance at the end.

Tynan's fine portrait of him misinterpreted the diffidence and humility. Guinness, Tynan wrote, "never will be a star in the sense that Olivier isHe does everything by stealthHe will illumine many a blind alley of subtlety, but blaze no trailsHis stage presence is quite without amplitude; and his face, except when, temporarily, make-up transfigures it, is a signless zero."

The suggestiveness, the wish to avoid being domineering, was a different sort of contract with the audience's imagination. Guinness also wielded glacial fierceness and terror with authority.

His greatness materialised without Olivier's showmanship, Richardson's abandoned cussedness, and Gielgud's resonant lyricism. Tynan admired but was inclined to patronise Guinness's poetry and versatility.

At 24, in 1951, the critic was engaged by Guinness as Player King in his second Hamlet. Guinness invested much amour propre in this production. Tynan called it "Hamlet with the pilot dropped" and said it was cast with "exuberant oddness". Its failure turned out to be a major factor in Guinness's move away from the classics and Shakespeare and into films, ultimately television, and new plays.

Tynan found Guinness less potent in the classical arena because he expected actors to perform like concerto soloists. I did not see Guinness's inspirational Richard II for Ralph Richardson's Old Vic company at the New theatre (now Albery) in 1947. His Macbeth at the Royal Court (1966) was certainly a quiet, clipped tragic victim without the expected sexiness and physicality, and handicapped by Simone Signoret's characterful, impossibly Gallic English as Lady M. (Gielgud's 1961 Stratford Othello was also criticised for lacking diapason.)

In fact, Guinness was an actor for a new theatrical style, subtle and undecorated. From the 1960s in the West End he mostly created roles in new plays rather than challenging memories of Gielgud, Richardson or Olivier. He might have been a marvellous and unusual Lear, but when he took the role on radio it was underwhelming.

Though his work in Alan Bennett's plays was superb, he was far less inclined, at the end of his career, to accept the sort of risks that Gielgud - secure in a theatrical dynasty - famously did with Pinter, David Storey and Julian Mitchell.

He was always a bit of a social upstart in an English theatre world full of great families, a self-made actor with no advantages, spotted by Gielgud and Guthrie, but dependent on a very spiritual stillness and charisma. When in the mid-seventies I first met Guinness, who had long been an idol, he had a slightly grand shyness off-stage. Yet, of all the great British stage actors, his was the busiest film career, for which his modest way of acting was unrivalled.

He was not only an actor. He was good at drawing and produced a charming, diffident design for his own Christmas cards each year. Like Caruso he was a natural at caricatures, especially of himself. He was also a very able author.

His adaptation of The Brothers Karamazov, directed by Peter Brook in 1946, marked his return to the stage (as Mitya) after war service in the Royal Navy. Earlier, just before the war, his stage version of Great Expectations (later the basis of David Lean's film) had been directed by George Devine.

After playing Herbert Pocket in Lean's Great Expectations, and Fagin in Oliver Twist, he went on to a series of glorious Ealing comedies - perhaps most memorably as the crook Henry Holland in Crichton's Lavender Hill Mob, and as Professor Marcus, another crook in Mackendrick's Ladykillers.

His greatest film role was probably Colonel Nicholson in Lean's Bridge on the River Kwai (1957), where his quintessentially English stiff upper lip and obsessive unreasonableness under, eventually, dreadful Japanese maltreatment won him an Oscar and numerous other prizes.

Further award-winning work included the artist Gulley Jimson in The Horse's Mouth, with his own screenplay based on Joyce Carey's novel. It was a pity that his brilliantly unpleasant Scottish impersonation of Jock Sinclair in Tunes of Glory (1960) was not followed by a lot of other good starring roles with the exception of Dorrit in Christine Edzard's epic Dickens adaptation. He settled mostly for lucrative supporting parts in various blockbusters, including Cromwell, The Comedians and The Quiller Memorandum.

Some were quite distinguished - like Lean's Doctor Zhivago, Lawrence of Arabia and A Passage to India. In The Fall of the Roman Empire, his Marcus Aurelius was one of the film's few redeeming features. Little Dorrit and his television appearances in Le Carré's Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy and its sequels, were effectively his screen monument.

Guinness was a charming, fascinating and elusive companion. He did not enjoy playing the star, though he liked the respect he got when visiting famous restaurants. He lived in a modest way ouside Petersfield from the mid-1950s, with a large garden that much occupied his wife Merula. He had a small circle of particular friends, many outside the theatre. For years he and Merula were close to Rachel Kempson and Michael Redgrave. He was knighted in 1959.

If one visited him in his dressing room in the West End in the 1970s one might find a surprisingly broad collection of people there, many of whom were never destined to discover what the others' link with the great actor might be. He preferred to keep his friends separate: a one to one person. He liked good food and drink. His favourite London hotel for years was the Connaught, with its superb cuisine. He was essentially not a club man. Anybody outside his close immediate circle was intrigued by the Guinness enigma.

But the reserve through which that attractive generosity and warmth powerfully shone was, for him, an impenetrable and necessary protection.

It can't possibly have been intentional. The August edition of Nova, which opened with a jokey and seasonal editor's letter - a postcard simply saying Deborah Bee is on holiday - arrived on the same day as the news that Bee's holiday was going to be an exceptionally long one.

As is so often the case with new magazines, Bee is leaving the job after producing only a handful of issues.

Whether she was as proactive about standing down as her employers IPC would like to make out is of course open to question. The industry rumour suggests that IPC was not happy with the millennial relaunch of the 1960s icon. There's nothing like a bad advertising audit to upset the company applecart, and Nova has seemed a little on the light side in pagination. But the magazine's publisher, Elaine Foran, insists it is "definitely on budget" - not just on target, in fact, but better than IPC had hoped in terms of both circulation and advertising.

There is also the question of whether Bee was happy to go. She is still answering her phone but unable, she politely regrets, to answer any questions at the moment.

Nova has not had an easy ride since it reappeared on May 4. The 1960s incarnation of the magazine is upheld by designers and journalists as a truly provocative, trail-blazing, mould-breaking publication, in which the images and layouts shouted as loudly as the campaigning words.

Looking back over those old issues (it stayed the course from 1965 until IPC pulled it in the mid-70s), not many of them measure up to its shining reputation. The ones that do, however, where the directness and sheer courage of an idea is not naive but genuinely confrontational, are remarkable: a cover image of a black man with a single cover line asking if you would really want him to be your neighbour still sends a shiver down the spine.

"The idea of the relaunch stank from the start," says Chris Hemblade, acting editor of Time Out and former features editor of Scene, the now-defunct fashion magazine where Bee was editor. "Every art director uses Nova as a model, an ideal. But this relaunch felt like a bunch of publishing executives wanting to bring back something they'd felt good about in the past. It was bound to be a poor imitation."

The view from IPC is, as you'd expect, quite different. "Everything Nova stands for is all the vogue again," says Julie York, the company's director of corporate communications. "That 60s and 70s thing."

Such literalism seems rather ingenuous from such a giant of publishing. The prevailing "60s and 70s thing" emerges from the fact that many current opinion- and taste-makers and media-ites grew up in the 60s and 70s. Their - our - take on the world is certainly informed by values from those decades, but it is liberally reinterpreted for the society we live in today.

To be fair to Bee, her original plan wasn't to redo Nova. Bee, then editor of Scene, approached IPC along with Scene's features editor, David Roberts, and its art director, Gerard Saint, with an idea for an intelligent high-fashion magazine aimed at 18- to 25-year-old women. They reckoned there was a gap in the market and that they could produce a niche product to fill it.

IPC had long toyed with the idea of a Nova relaunch - it nearly happened 10 years ago, but came out as Marie Claire instead. "It was something being talked about," says Elaine Foran. "And then Deborah came up with an idea that was so similar that we put the two ideas together."

Now Jeremy Langmead is waiting to fill Bee's still-warm seat, and hoping to take over early in October. He has been the editor of the Sunday Times Style magazine for the past five years and sees Nova as "a creative challenge".

Echoing the words of Bee, Roberts et al, he describes his reader as "intelligent, twenty-something, fashion conscious - Stella McCartney or Chloe Sevigny". (Let's hope he really means those who aspire to be SM and CS, or he might be terribly disappointed.) He is convinced that there is an elusive gap somewhere between Vogue and Elle.

"I feel confident," he enthuses. "About having a market, knowing it's there. Vogue has got older - it's Lady Helen Windsor and Mario Testino. And Elle's gone much younger - it's the Denise Van Outen of women's magazines. So I'm pitching between the mummies and the dummies."

Langmead's profile has recently been raised by the publicity surrounding a novel by his ex, India Knight, in which some claimed to see parallels between him and the heroine's husband.

Mischievously witty, he is known for his skill and tact in handling contributors, having cultivated AA Gill as Style's restaurant critic and Tara Palmer-Tomkinson as a columnist. The Style section has a formidable record as a launchpad (alumnae include the novelists Helen Fielding and Wendy Holden). The experience of seeing his deputy Liz Jones - now occupying Tara P-T's old slot in Style with her Bridget Jones-style column - chosen as editor of Marie Claire might well have convinced him that it was time to move on.

Langmead's suitability, according to Foran, is his experience. "He can manage a large team and recognise good writing. And he understands how a fashion magazine works."

He will undoubtedly take people with him, and Nova will inevitably shed a few more original staff. Fashion-pack gossip suggests that Venetia Scott, the fashion director, could walk, taking not just her husband, photographer Juergen Teller, but a whole raft of heavyweight names, including photographers Terry Richardson and David Sims and stylist Nancy Rhode.

It's a group of people summed up by one insider as "having enough clout to work between Vogue and iD, if they choose to". If they go, a great deal of the title's credibility goes with them. But the idea of credibility hangs heavy here. And that isn't Nova's or anyone else's fault, but the problem in general with general-interest magazines, even those focused on fashion.

For all the potential twenty-something readers out there, it's a group that has proven to be notoriously fickle and since it knows how to access information from a variety of places and media - television and the internet are huge providers - is less likely to be loyal to one magazine.

When it does come to print, magazines seem to function better the more tightly they are bound to one subject. Outstanding among current successful titles are Mixmag, the dance culture bible, and Wallpaper, the aspirational design bible. Both offer finely honed content to readers according to a specific interest rather than a demographic evaluation.

That, along with Nova's difficult heritage, has so far stood in the way of it relaxing into a comfortable role. An ex-employee of Frank, the Wagadon title launched in 1997 that took a stab at a similar market, says: "It has made an effort to take on the values of old Nova - to be a strong, meaty, social read, dealing with bigger issues. But although we do want to be made aware, pulling it off in this context is very difficult."

Under pressure to reflect the title's earlier interests, we get Celia Brayfield on why women are still underachieving in the 21st century. With no disrespect to the writer, it made me think I was back in the 70s being lectured by someone's well-meaning mother in a pine-filled kitchen in Camden.

Langmead needs to hold on to his fashion team, which is what currently makes this product into the jewel in the crown that IPC wants it to be. He wants to get rid of the magazine's slightly irritable tone, and introduce a softer, more comforting voice.

Twenty-something girls might be a prickly, strident bunch these days, but it's dangerous - and unwelcoming - to interpret that too literally. Magazines work by becoming familiar and friendly.

There's a reason that the idea of "curling up" with them has become a cliche. By his own admission, Langmead wants to "make it more bubbly, really heat it up". At least it's already warm.

Re-creation or poor imitation? Twenty-five years on and off Carolyne Ellis

The original Nova was part of its time, it's a different time now, so it's difficult to do the same thing. Nova's strength was that it was irreverent, clever and quite shocking, and visually very strong. There are a lot of magazines these days and to succeed you must be different. Alexandra Shulman, Vogue

It was a good idea to revive the title, but I don't know how relevant that style of journalism - provocative and groundbreaking then - is now. There's little that shocks today. The magazine was pretty much what we expected - edgy and niche. And if that's what they tried to create, then they've achieved it. Fiona McIntosh, Elle

I love the [first] cover. It was a nice mix of the 60s and the year 2000. I love the model, I love the fashion - it's nice having a purely fashion magazine again. Some of it does try to please too much. It's a little bit prickly, not apologising about anything. It says, 'this is what we do and if you don't like it, that's tough'. Liz Jones, Marie Claire

They've got a strong team and the cover and the logo are strong, too. But I felt that it fell between two stools: it was not for the London hipster and it was not mainstream either. I don't think it's a timely or a clever idea. I have been a big fan of the original, but for a first issue it fell short of my expectations. Johnny Davis, The Face

From super Nova to not so super Nova

* The original Nova ran from 1965 to 1975 and achieved near mythic status. It re-wrote the rules of women's magazines and fashion journalism, becoming the 60s style bible.

* Previously women's magazines meant knitting patterns and cooking recipes. Homosexuality and abortion were taboo. Breaking down cultural, moral and sexual prejudices became Nova's aim. One 1967 cover story dealing with homosexual law reform showed two men above the words: "They consent in private". A 1969 cover featured child killer Mary Bell.

* Editor Dennis Hackett attributed Nova's success to its ability to appeal to both sexes: "We were read by women and men. We had a 42% male readership - the highest of any women's magazine."

* Contributors included home editor Janet Fitch, comic strip writer Peter Preston, cookery expert Elizabeth David, writer Penny Vincenzi and astrologer Patrick Walker.

* But by the early 70s Nova was losing its editorial and innovatory edge. IPC decided to kill the title in 1975.

* On announcing last November that Nova was going to be revived 25 years on, IPC insisted it was not a nostalgia trip - the free, incisive spirit of the original would be preserved but adapted to the concerns of 21st-century women.
